ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I strengthened my design thinking skills during this course. I also became more familiar with using Rhino as a tool.
Model making skills, clearer 2D representation of diagrams, plans, and sections.
Deeper technical skills in Sketchup, Adobe Illustrator + Photoshop, physical model making, and making presentations. Knowledge in architectural language, references, and representation styles.

Huge leap forward for me in developing a formal design process! 

The first studio where we really iterated, developed, tried understanding a building though so many fundamental lenses.
Learned more about the design process, understood the first few steps in designing a building for people.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I thought a strength of the course was having the structure of the different exercises since this was the first building-scale project for us. The pace of the exercises and pin-ups felt manageable too. 

For me, a weakness was the way desk crits were held. I think it would have been more helpful for our TFs to meet with us separately from the professors, so that we did not have to wait so long to talk to someone. I also thought the idea of splitting into 2 groups made sense at first, but in the end it meant we were really only getting feedback from one TF when the TFs had different skill sets and I think I would have benefitted from both.
Program could be introduced earlier in the semester; site plan/collaborative quality w cohort was limited (but understandably difficult to coordinate)

Professors and TAs are very engaged, ensuring students get the feedback they need to progress.

Workload is very high but that should be expected....

Strengths: two professors and two TAs were really beneficial since all students got equal attention and feedback. The assignments and deliverables were clear from the handout packets for each step of the project. I thought the entire design process was quite unique and exciting, i.e. starting from the Albers piece, creating a figure, doubling the figure, then thinking about circulation etc. That broke the whole process of design down in a fun, manageable, and memorable way. 

Weaknesses: I wonder if having more information about the next design step in the current design step would have made the entire process smoother. For example, I think the deliverables for "program" were a larger jump from the previous "aggregate" than any of the earlier assignments because we had not been thinking about what was actually going on in the building until that point. As an aspiring designer, that experience was quite fun but felt a little detached from reality. Maybe encouraging students to think more about the building program earlier on would have helped some of us create more successful projects.
Teaching excellent, TAs so available, well structured in terms of breadth and number of assignments

Strengths were the teaching staff and the feedback that was given each step of the process. The number of deliverables and assignments often felt unachievable for undergraduate students and I think that could use some improvement.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Studio is a special type of class that you can't get elsewhere
Yes (well if you're looking at this course you are probably studying architecture and it's kind of late to back out now). But yes! great class and I grew a lot from this project.
If you are on the design track, yes, and you have to!
Only those who are interested and passionate about architecture.
